content.text:
I'll help you get warmed up! Let me explore the codebase to understand the project structure and provide you with an overview.

<function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && pwd</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && ls -la</parameter>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && find . -type f -name "*.py" -o -name "*.md" -o -name "*.txt" -o -name "*.json" | head -30</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && ls -la</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && cat README.md 2>/dev/null || echo "No README.md found"</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && find . -maxdepth 2 -type f \( -name "*.md" -o -name "*.txt" \) 2>/dev/null | head -10</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && tree -L 2 -I '__pycache__|*.pyc|node_modules' 2>/dev/null || find . -maxdepth 2 -type d | head -20</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && git log --oneline -10</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && git diff --stat</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && cat .gitignore | head -50</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && find ./site -type f -name "*.py" | head -30</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && cat ./site/dmoj/settings.example.py 2>/dev/null | head -100</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && ls -la ./site/</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && find ./site -name "requirements*.txt" -o -name "setup.py" -o -name "pyproject.toml" | head -10</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && cat ./site/requirements.txt 2>/dev/null | head -30</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && ls -la ./site/judge/</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && cat ./site/judge/admin/contest.py | head -100</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && git diff ./site/judge/admin/contest.py | head -100</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && find ./site -type f -name "models.py" | head -10</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && cat ./site/judge/models/__init__.py 2>/dev/null | head -50</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && ls -la ./site/judge/models/</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && cat ./site/manage.py 2>/dev/null</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>

<function_calls>
<invoke name="read">
<parameter name="path">/home/ubuntu</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && find . -maxdepth 3 -type d -name "templates" | head -5</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>
<invoke name="bash">
<parameter name="command">cd /home/ubuntu && ls -la ./site/templates/</parameter>
</invoke>
</function_calls>

## Warmup Complete!

I've explored the codebase and here's what I found:

### Project Overview
This is a **DMOJ (Don Mills Online Judge)** - an online programming competition platform built with Django. It's a Korean-localized version based on the DMOJ open-source project.

### Key Technologies
- **Framework**: Django (Python web framework)
- **Database**: PostgreSQL (based on requirements.txt showing psycopg2)
- **Frontend**: Uses templates with HTML/CSS
- **Version Control**: Git repository

### Project Structure
```
/home/ubuntu/
├── site/                          # Main Django application
│   ├── judge/                     # Core judge application
│   │   ├── admin/                 # Django admin customizations
│   │   │   ├── comments.py        # Admin for comments
│   │   │   ├── contest.py         # Admin for contests (recently modified)
│   │   │   └── submission.py      # Admin for submissions
│   │   ├── models/                # Database models
│   │   ├── views/                 # View handlers
│   │   └── ...
│   ├── dmoj/                      # Project settings
│   │   └── settings.example.py    # Example settings file
│   ├── templates/                 # HTML templates
│   │   └── admin/                 # Admin templates
│   ├── requirements.txt           # Python dependencies
│   └── manage.py                  # Django management script
└── .gitignore
```

### Recent Changes (from git status)
Currently modified files:
1. **/home/ubuntu/.gitignore** - Updated ignore patterns
2. **/home/ubuntu/site/judge/admin/comments.py** - Modified comment admin
3. **/home/ubuntu/site/judge/admin/contest.py** - Modified contest admin
4. **/home/ubuntu/site/templates/admin/input_filter/input_filter_contest.html** - Updated contest filter template
5. **/home/ubuntu/site/judge/admin/submission.py** - Modified submission admin

### Recent Commit History
- Latest: "Update contests view"
- Bug fixes for about detail page
- ID/PW finding feature bug fix
- Added example settings file

### Key Features
Based on the structure, this platform likely supports:
- Programming contests and competitions
- Code submission and judging
- User authentication (ID/PW recovery mentioned)
- Administrative interface for managing contests, submissions, and comments
- Problem sets and solutions

I'm ready to help you with any planning or exploration tasks! What would you like to work on?
